title: High resolution nerve ultrasound in neurofibromatosis type 1: a prospective and descriptive study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To explore the value of high resolution nerve ultrasound (HRUS) RESULTS: Sixty patients were enrolled, 37 in the PNS group and 23 in the non-PNS group. HRUS was abnormal in 52 patients (87 %), 34 in the PNS group (92 %) and 18 in the non-PNS group (78 %, p = 0.24). Patients with continuous nerve enlargements (high PN tumor load) were easily distinguished with HRUS. 85 % of patients with normal NCS have nerve enlargements on HRUS. CONCLUSIONS: HRUS helps to assess PN tumor burden in NF1. NCS did not have additional value. SIGNIFICANCE: HRUS might be useful as a screening tool for PN in NF1, especially in settings with less MRI availability.
authors: D Christine Noordhoek; Tessa A Ennik; Sarah A van Dijk; Eline Mann; Sophie van der Vlist; Judith Drenthen; Walter Taal
journal: Clinical neurophysiology : official journal of the International Federation of Clinical Neurophysiology
